page.title: 13ST. BUDEAUX & ERNESETTLE
page.content: {St.Budeaux} On the western edge of Plymouth near the river Tamar lies St.Budeaux, named after a Celtic saint,'St.Budoc'. He sailed from France in 480 a.d. landing at Tamerton creek mudflats bringing Christianity to the area. 100 years ago St.Budeaux was mainly an area of green fields,today it is a heavily populated urban area affected by the modern problem of traffic congestion. {Ernesettle Battery} Built in 1868,it was one of a series of military ports defending Plymouth's coastline.It originally was used as barrocks for 60 men,to mount 15 canons and 6 mortars.Today it is used as a Royal Navel ammunitions depot where in underground vaults the Navy's missiles are stored.
